text: Patient: Okay. Alright. Family Member: If he has non-cancer issues, he goes to him primary? Patient: Primary doctor, correct? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah, they’re smarter than us. Family Member: If he thinks he has a hernia, would that show on the CT scan? Would that be appropriate to send to the doctor? Doctor: No, because, yeah, the hernia, you know, when you’re laying down it really has to be pretty bad for it to be seen laying down. It’s usually when you’re standing up or sitting that it comes out. A hernia just means you have a weak area of muscle and then you have your bowel spill out. Typically, it doesn’t bother you unless it gets stuck, you know. Patient: Okay. Family Member: He’s having a lot of pain shooting up. Patient: Just I have a problem with my groin Doctor: Yeah.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. (pause) Patient: Okay. So, uh, if, so I guess the, the question is stay on this, this um, a clinic, stay in the clinical trial. Let’s see what happens the next, you know, three months from now. Doctor: Right. Patient: Is one option. And what other options are there? Doctor: Yeah. So, other options would be then we would stop this therapy and say that hey, you know, all the data says it’s gotten worse. Um, and, then we would look at other treatments. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: They’ve had Radium. You’ve got Abiraterone. You’ve got Enzalutamide. So, we would look at possibly chemotherapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, off, uh, clinical studies, chemotherapy would be, uh, the reasonable next step --- Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We’ve got Taxotere, uh, would be what we would use. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: No. I still wake up a couple of times a night you know and go but uh other than that I’m pretty active, play golf a couple of times a week. You know? Nothing slows me down. And I, I mean it looks like unfortunately there’s been some changes that probably we’ll, we will have to call off the study. Patient: Oh is that right? Doctor: Yeah. Uh so the PSA to start with went up just a little, uh, so. Patient: It’s up around forty something isn’t it? Family Member: Six. Doctor: So it was forty-six, forty-three, forty-nine. So that’s almost the same number to me, maybe a little bit elevated from the last time. And then uh the bone scan we did looks pretty much the same. There’s really nothing new. Well that’s been there for- Doctor: Yeah. So that, that really, they don’t really see anything new. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
